Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Inorganic, Bioinorganic, and Organometallic Chemistry program supports work by Professor Chad A, Mirkin at Northwestern University to study functional coordination chemistry-based systems. The laboratory is utilizing a synthetic methodology for the preparation of flexible supramolecular complexes known as the Weak-Link Approach (WLA), resulting in structures that allow one to access multiple geometries in situ. Using this coordination-chemistry approach, the laboratory is targeting allosteric and heteroligated systems with unique functions that cannot easily be accessed using alternative strategies based on conventional coordination- or organic chemistry. Through this work, the laboratory will design: (1) novel detection systems with signal amplification capabilities that have true "off-on" capabilities in terms of the allosterically regulated catalytic event; (2) structures with recognition groups that can orient a complex substrate for the regioselective catalytic functionalization of the substrate; and (3) systems that can function in aqueous media (without organic co-solvents. Practical application of many of the amplification systems demonstrated thus far will require the ability for such complexes to function in water.
The work will lead to a new class of highly sensitive and selective chemical detection systems for analytes that are hazardous to the environment and new catalysts capable of effecting high value chemical transformations. In addition, postdoctoral associates, graduate students, and undergraduate students trained through this work will gains skills that make them highly competitive in the US chemical industry. An emphasis will be placed on including women and under-represented minorities in the three year effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes are essential biological catalysts that accelerate the rate of specific reactions and can be regulated by small molecules. Supramolecular structures, chemical systems comprising a discrete number of assembled molecular subunits, are ideal platforms for the development of enzyme mimics because they can exhibit functional and structural complexity via metal-directed assembly processes. Consequently, for decades, supramolecular inorganic chemists have been pursuing the synthesis of structures that mimic enzyme reactivity, with the goal of both developing synthetically useful enzymatically-inspired catalysts and understanding fundamental questions pertaining to the function of these enzyme mimics.

Researchers in this project focused on the synthesis of supramolecular enzyme mimics that exhibit molecular recognition and catalytic properties through the weak-link approach (WLA). This allows one to synthesize molecules that can be chemically toggled between rigid, condensed, and flexible open states. The project yielded several notable systems including a mimic of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) – a method of self-amplification of the building blocks of DNA, in which a pathway was established to design complexes with PCR-like properties that extend beyond DNA-based substrates. The researchers also developed a WLA-assembled supramolecular structure with a triple-layer geometry that can be used to regulate a polymerization reaction. This triple-layer motif is the first system that allows for the incorporation of monometallic catalysts into WLA systems, which can be turned on and off with almost no background and side reactions. The expansion of WLA systems from bimetallic to monometallic structures opens up myriad possibilities in the area of regulated catalysis.

Researchers also gained a greater understanding of the fundamental chemistry involved in the synthesis of WLA-based enzyme mimics. Significant achievements include an understanding of the small-molecule-induced regulation of WLA complexes, thus expanding the number of target metal centers that can be used in these systems. These developments led to the discovery of an unprecedented reaction that can produce new supramolecular structures. The development of WLA-based supramolecular structures during the course of this grant has laid the fundamental foundation for creating a new class of regulated catalysts and high-sensitivity molecular diagnostic tools.

The broader impacts of this research include the training of a diverse group of researchers (11 graduate students, 6 postdoctoral associates, and 6 undergraduate students) in the areas of supramolecular, inorganic, and organometallic chemistry. Researchers also gained extensive hands-on experience in synthesis, catalysis, and spectroscopy. Every researcher who has worked on this general project since its inception has gained employment in either academic or industrial settings. Additionally, approximately half of the graduate students and one third of the undergraduates funded by the NSF over the past three years were from underrepresented groups.
